alexander.goal: Agree on a 30-minute meeting time within Monday 09:00-17:00 that fits everyone's schedules.

elizabeth.goal: Agree on a 30-minute meeting time within Monday 09:00-17:00 that fits everyone's schedules.

walter.goal: Agree on a 30-minute meeting time within Monday 09:00-17:00 that fits everyone's schedules.

private_information: Role: Audit temporal/causal consistency, eliminate bookkeeping shortcuts, and verify intersection of free slots.
consistency_auditor.goal: Ensure the proposed availability windows are consistent, intersect them correctly, and identify feasible meeting slots that comply with constraints and preferences.

private_information: Role: Integrate audited availability and produce a final PDDL domain and problem targeting the Fast Downward solver.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a final plan and corresponding PDDL domain and problem that schedule the meeting at a feasible time that satisfies all constraints and preferences.

public_information: Task: Schedule a 30-minute meeting for Alexander, Elizabeth, and Walter on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00.
Preference: If multiple valid slots exist, choose the earliest feasible slot.

availability.system_prompt: You analyze calendar constraints and compute your free 30-minute windows within the specified working hours. Do not produce PDDL. Return a concise list of candidate time intervals in ascending order using the format HH:MM-HH:MM.
availability.prompt: Your name is Alexander. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Private information: {agents->alexander->private_information}. Goal: {agents->alexander->goal}. Produce your available 30-minute slots for Monday between 09:00 and 17:00 that do not overlap your busy times. Output only the list of slots.

availability.system_prompt: You analyze calendar constraints and compute your free 30-minute windows within the specified working hours. Do not produce PDDL. Return a concise list of candidate time intervals in ascending order using the format HH:MM-HH:MM.
availability.prompt: Your name is Elizabeth. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Private information: {agents->elizabeth->private_information}. Goal: {agents->elizabeth->goal}. Produce your available 30-minute slots for Monday between 09:00 and 17:00 that do not overlap your busy times. Output only the list of slots.

availability.system_prompt: You analyze calendar constraints and compute your free 30-minute windows within the specified working hours. Do not produce PDDL. Return a concise list of candidate time intervals in ascending order using the format HH:MM-HH:MM.
availability.prompt: Your name is Walter. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Private information: {agents->walter->private_information}. Goal: {agents->walter->goal}. Produce your available 30-minute slots for Monday between 09:00 and 17:00 that do not overlap your busy times. Output only the list of slots.

audit.system_prompt: You audit temporal and causal consistency across multiple participants' availability windows. Verify formatting, normalize to aligned 30-minute slots within work hours, intersect the sets, and remove any bookkeeping shortcuts such as assumed slack tokens or post-hoc penalties. Do not produce PDDL. Output only the mutually free slots and indicate the earliest feasible slot if a preference for earliest exists.
audit.prompt: Inputs from participants: {availability_alexander} {availability_elizabeth} {availability_walter}. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Return the intersection of free 30-minute slots that are within Monday 09:00-17:00 and satisfy the meeting duration. Present a short list of mutually available slots and clearly mark the earliest feasible slot.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with PDDL for the Fast Downward planner. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that encode selecting one 30-minute time slot for the meeting using discretized 30-minute slots. Use STRIPS-compatible predicates supported by Fast Downward. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> and the problem between <problem></problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: Use the audited availability and environment context to generate a final PDDL domain and problem that select one allowed slot for the meeting. The domain should be generic for scheduling a single meeting among participants over discrete time slots. The problem should instantiate the concrete time slots for this task and set a goal that the meeting is scheduled at a permissible slot, preferring the earliest feasible slot when available. Inputs: {audited_availability}. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Ensure the final output contains exactly one <domain>...</domain> block and one <problem>...</problem> block suitable for Fast Downward.
